study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of group-delivered mindfulness-based stress reduction versus a waitlist control group on pain, emotional function, quality of life, and global impression of change among breast cancer survivors with chronic neuropathic pain (CNP).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in pain interference scores or secondary outcomes between the mindfulness-based stress reduction group and the waitlist control group, suggesting no measurable benefits of the intervention for CNP management in this population.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors with chronic neuropathic pain (CNP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of a modular psychotherapy approach (MoBa) integrating mindfulness-based cognitive therapy for treating depression in patients with comorbidities and childhood maltreatment.
results_summary: The study will assess the feasibility and efficacy of MoBa, which includes mindfulness-based cognitive therapy, compared to standard cognitive-behavioral therapy, with outcomes measured post-treatment and at 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Outpatients with episodic or persistent major depression, comorbidity, and a history of childhood maltreatment (N=70).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of an adapted MBCT intervention for people with mild dementia and depression and explore its potential benefits compared to treatment as usual (TAU).
results_summary: The MBCT intervention was feasible in terms of attendance and attrition but did not show significant improvements in depression, anxiety, quality of life, or cognition compared to TAU. Recruitment within the timeframe was also deemed unfeasible.
population_specificity: People with mild dementia and depression recruited from memory services.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Interventions (MBIs) like MBSR, MBCT, and MBCR in reducing symptoms of depression, anxiety, and cancer-related fatigue (CRF) in oncology populations.
results_summary: MBIs showed significant medium effects in reducing depression (Hedges' g = 0.43), anxiety (Hedges' g = 0.55), and CRF (Hedges' g = 0.43), with benefits lasting at least three months post-intervention. MBIs were superior to control groups for anxiety and CRF, but not for depression at follow-up.
population_specificity: Oncology patients (cancer, neoplasm, lymphoma, carcinoma, sarcoma).
study_duration: At least three months post-intervention (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the empirical evidence for the perioperative use of mindfulness interventions and propose a mindfulness-based stepped care approach for managing preoperative pain, anxiety, and postoperative complications.
results_summary: The study found strong evidence supporting mindfulness techniques in alleviating clinical symptoms relevant to surgical contexts, including preoperative pain and anxiety, and preventing postoperative chronic pain or opioid misuse. More extensive mindfulness interventions were effective for patients with persistent high pain levels or prolonged opioid use after surgery.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing surgical procedures, particularly those at risk for chronic pain or opioid misuse.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of guided mobile-based perinatal mindfulness intervention (GMBPMI) on reducing psychological distress and improving heart rate variability (HRV) in pregnant women.
results_summary: The study expects GMBPMI to reduce maternal psychological stress and improve mindfulness, HRV, and overall psychological and physical wellbeing, with potential benefits extending into the postpartum period.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in their second trimester (12th to 20th week gestation) experiencing psychological distress.
study_duration: Measured at baseline, post-intervention, 36-week gestation, and five-week postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether mindfulness intervention combined with behavioral treatment (BT) improved behavior, executive functioning, and mindful awareness in children with ADHD.
results_summary: The study found no incremental benefits of mindfulness when combined with intensive BT for observed child behavior, attention, inhibitory control, or mindful awareness.
population_specificity: Elementary-aged children with ADHD (N = 58) in a controlled summer program setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mobile health app (oVRcome) combining mindfulness, cognitive techniques, and virtual reality exposure therapy for reducing specific phobia symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that the oVRcome app significantly reduced the severity of specific phobia symptoms compared to a waitlist control group, with a mean change in symptom severity scores favoring the active intervention. Mindfulness was included as part of a multi-component approach, but its individual contribution was not isolated.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-64 in New Zealand with self-reported fears of flying, heights, spiders, dogs, or needles and a score above 4 on the Brief Standard Self-rating scale for phobic patients.
effective_dosage: Six modules over 6 weeks (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a pre-operative mindfulness session (via audio file) combined with post-operative treatment as usual (TAU) in preventing chronic pain and fatigue after breast cancer surgery.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the efficacy of mindfulness; the study is ongoing and aims to compare outcomes between intervention and control groups at 3 and 12 months post-surgery.
population_specificity: Women undergoing breast cancer surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (pre-operative one-session mindfulness via audio file).
study_duration: Pre-operative session and post-operative follow-up at 3 and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness practice reduces affect spin (emotional reactivity) in employees and whether this reduction is associated with lower emotional exhaustion and higher job satisfaction.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness practice reduces affect spin over time, and lower affect spin is linked to reduced emotional exhaustion and increased job satisfaction at both between- and within-person levels.
population_specificity: Employees (specific industry or demographic details not provided in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of mindfulness yoga on emotional disorders, fatigue, pain, and health-related quality of life in early-stage breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The mindfulness yoga group showed significant improvements in anxiety, depression, and health-related quality of life compared to the control group, but no significant differences were found for fatigue and pain.
population_specificity: Early-stage breast cancer patients who had received adjuvant chemotherapy.
study_duration: 8 weeks (assessed at baseline, 8th week, and 20th week)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of mindfulness training on burnout, depression, anxiety, and stress among nonmedical hospital staff.
results_summary: Mindfulness training significantly reduced work-distaste-related burnout, client-related burnout, anxiety, and stress immediately after the intervention, with effects remaining stable for at least three months. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Nonmedical staff in a hospital in Shiraz, Iran.
study_duration: Duration of training not specified; follow-up at T1 (immediately post-intervention) and T2 (3 months post-intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on physical function outcomes in individuals with chronic low back pain (CLBP).
results_summary: MBSR therapy showed significant improvement in physical function at 8 weeks and 6 months follow-up in CLBP individuals, with notable between-group differences in RMDQ scores. However, further high-quality RCTs are needed to confirm long-term effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic low back pain (CLBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness-based mandala activity on reducing anxiety levels and improving spiritual well-being in nursing students transitioning to clinical practice after distance education during COVID-19.
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in anxiety levels and a significant improvement in spiritual well-being scores in the intervention group compared to the control group after three mindfulness-based mandala sessions.
population_specificity: Nursing students starting clinical practice after distance education during COVID-19.
effective_dosage: Three mindfulness-based mandala sessions (specific duration per session not mentioned).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated (implied to be short-term, covering three sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physical and mental health outcomes and participant experiences of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) for couples over 65, including caregiving dyads and those with cognitive decline.
results_summary: The studies suggested that standardized eight-week mindfulness interventions may be feasible for older adult couples and caregiving dyads, but the evidence is limited and should be interpreted cautiously. Further high-quality studies with sensitive outcome measures are needed.
population_specificity: Couples over 65, including independent couples and caregiving dyads (some with cognitive decline).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of a hybrid (in-person and digital) mindfulness meditation intervention in reducing perceived stress among pediatric residents.
results_summary: The hybrid mindfulness intervention significantly reduced perceived stress in pediatric residents compared to controls, with a notable effect size (0.91). No significant differences were observed in secondary outcomes like burnout, depression, anxiety, loneliness, or sleep quality.
population_specificity: Pediatric residents (n = 66)
effective_dosage: One 60-minute in-person session plus 6-week access to a digital MAPs curriculum (average participation: 2 digital sessions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) versus Relapse Prevention-Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT-RP) for patients with treatment-refractory anxiety disorders and explore potential mediating variables.
results_summary: MBCT showed significantly greater reductions in anxiety, avoidance, emotion regulation difficulties, and worry, as well as increased mindfulness skills post-treatment, though gains diminished slightly after 6 months. No mediating variables were identified for MBCT's effects on anxiety.
population_specificity: 136 outpatients with DSM-IV-defined treatment-refractory anxiety disorders who had insufficient response to first-line psychological treatment.
study_duration: Post-treatment and 6-month follow-up (exact intervention duration not specified in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mindfulness- and self-compassion-based group intervention (MSCBI) with and without animal-assistance in reducing psychological distress in patients with acquired brain injury.
results_summary: Both MSCBI groups (with and without animal-assistance) significantly reduced psychological distress, with no difference between groups. The animal-assisted group showed higher improvements in emotional states (e.g., feeling secure, accepted) and better treatment adherence.
population_specificity: Patients with acquired brain injury (N=31).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based treatments as an alternative strategy for tobacco dependence, alongside other interventions.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based treatments were considered an alternative strategy with a lower level of recommendation compared to primary interventions like behavioral therapy or medication. The mean agreement with the recommendations reached 98%, but mindfulness was not a primary focus.
population_specificity: Individuals with tobacco-related disorders, including adolescents and pregnant women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review interventions, including mindfulness, that improved the wellbeing of newly-qualified junior doctors in the UK.
results_summary: The review found that mindfulness interventions, among others, were beneficial in improving junior doctor wellbeing and reducing anxiety and stress levels, though most studies had small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Newly-qualified junior doctors in the UK within their first five years post-qualification.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on depression, anxiety, fatigue, and health-related quality of life in individuals with upper motor neuron disorders (UMNDs).
results_summary: MBIs were found to be feasible and acceptable, with high participant satisfaction and notable improvements in depression, anxiety, fatigue, and quality of life. Greater relative improvements were observed compared to controls, particularly against passive controls.
population_specificity: Adults with upper motor neuron disorders (multiple sclerosis, brain injury including stroke, spinal cord injury, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness as part of mental health interventions for adolescents living with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness, alongside other interventions like cognitive behavioral therapy and parenting programs, shows promise in addressing mental health challenges among adolescents with HIV, contributing to improved quality of life and adherence to antiretroviral therapy.
population_specificity: Adolescents living with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa, facing poverty, familial stress, and service gaps.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness as part of mind-body interventions in alleviating cancer-related fatigue (CRF) and sleep disturbances in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness, as a component of multicomponent interventions, may help alleviate CRF and sleep disturbances in cancer patients, though specific efficacy details are not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with cancer experiencing cancer-related fatigue and sleep disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a 10-week mindful eating program versus a mindfulness program and a no-treatment control group in improving dietary behavior and reducing binge eating among low-income overweight women.
results_summary: Both intervention groups showed improved eating behavior and reduced binge eating post-intervention and at follow-up, but no significant changes in weight or most biological tests. The mindful eating group performed slightly better than the mindfulness and control groups.
population_specificity: Adult, low-income women with a BMI ≥ 25 to < 40 receiving primary health care in São Paulo, Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of teaching mindfulness as part of Dialectical Behaviour Therapy (DBT) on clinical outcomes, focusing on self-reported mindfulness and psychological measures.
results_summary: The review found that mindfulness in DBT increased self-reported mindfulness, particularly non-judgemental awareness, and improved psychological measures like attention. Some clinical symptoms, such as those of Borderline Personality Disorder, showed positive effects, though not all studies controlled for confounding factors like group effects or other DBT elements.
population_specificity: Clinical populations, including individuals with Borderline Personality Disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether baseline characteristics (e.g., fatigue severity, fatigue catastrophizing) moderated the effectiveness of web-based mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (eMBCT) compared to other interventions for chronic cancer-related fatigue (CCRF).
results_summary: The study found that patients with low baseline fatigue severity and catastrophizing benefited more from activity feedback (AAF), while those with high fatigue severity and catastrophizing benefited more from eMBCT compared to psycho-education (PE). These results suggest personalized treatment may improve effectiveness.
population_specificity: Cancer patients suffering from chronic cancer-related fatigue (CCRF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore novel cognitive-behavioral approaches, including mindfulness-based interventions, for treating substance-related disorders by targeting dysregulated neurocognitive processes.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that mindfulness-based interventions may help individuals with substance use disorders cope with stress and craving-inducing cues, potentially improving treatment outcomes. However, specific results for mindfulness alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals with substance-related disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors related to fear of hypoglycemia in parents of children/adolescents with type 1 diabetes, including the role of mindfulness.
results_summary: The study found that psychological factors, including mindfulness, were associated with parental fear of hypoglycemia, suggesting mindfulness may play a role in mitigating this fear.
population_specificity: Parents of children and adolescents with type 1 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based meditation in reducing pain, both in chronic pain patients and experimentally induced pain models.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based meditation was found effective in reducing pain in chronic pain patients and healthy participants with experimentally induced pain, with identified neural mechanisms explaining short-term and sustained pain relief.
population_specificity: Chronic pain patients and healthy participants in experimentally induced pain models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a smartphone application incorporating mindfulness-based coaching could improve diabetes self-management behaviors and prevent complications.
results_summary: The intervention group showed improved self-management behaviors (dietary control, exercise, glucose monitoring, medication adherence, and complication screening) and better clinical outcomes compared to the control group. Mindfulness was part of a broader coaching approach, but its specific contribution was not isolated.
population_specificity: Individuals with diabetes mellitus (DM).
effective_dosage: Not specified (mindfulness was part of a multi-component intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of cognition in the sleep-aggression relationship and test the feasibility of a mindfulness-based cognitive approach to improve sleep and reduce aggression.
results_summary: The studies collectively demonstrated the importance of cognitive factors in the sleep-aggression relationship, with mindfulness being one of the interventions tested in a feasibility trial. The results suggested a need for further research to fully account for cognitive influences, as outlined in the proposed CoSMASH model.
population_specificity: Adult male forensic patients detained in a high secure hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether brief online stress reduction exercises, including mindful breathing, could reduce stress, arousal, and sleep difficulties in college students.
results_summary: The mindful breathing group showed improvements but was not significantly different from the self-monitoring control group at posttest, though it performed comparably to the progressive muscle relaxation group, which showed significant improvements.
population_specificity: College students experiencing stress and/or sleep difficulties.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether mindfulness practices could improve survival in cancer patients and explore potential mechanisms of action, such as reducing inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based interventions effectively reduce depressive symptoms and inflammation (e.g., cytokines, cortisol) in cancer patients, suggesting a potential link to improved survival, though long-term data are lacking.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with cancer experiencing depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of psychological interventions, including mindfulness and acceptance therapy, in reducing fear of cancer recurrence in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: Mindfulness and acceptance therapy-based interventions significantly reduced fear of cancer recurrence in breast cancer survivors. Short-term interventions (3-8 sessions) and face-to-face delivery were effective, while longer interventions (9+ sessions) and online delivery were not.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors
study_duration: Interventions with 3-8 sessions were effective; exact duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mediating role of nonattachment in the relationship between mindfulness and well-being and psychological distress, and to examine their respective associations after controlling for each other.
results_summary: Nonattachment partially mediated the associations between mindfulness and well-being and psychological distress. Both nonattachment and mindfulness were positively associated with well-being and negatively associated with psychological distress, even after controlling for each other.
population_specificity: 24,704 individuals across 41 independent cross-sectional datasets (general population, not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an 8-week mindfulness intervention (MI) could improve disease course, inflammatory markers, mindfulness, perceived stress, and psychological outcomes in inactive ulcerative colitis (UC) patients with limited or no prior exposure to MI.
results_summary: The MI significantly increased mindfulness and mindfulness skills, reduced perceived stress and stress response, and decreased the incidence of UC flares over 12 months (0% in MI group vs. 22% in controls).
population_specificity: Inactive ulcerative colitis patients with high perceived stress and low mindfulness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential mechanisms by which combined psilocybin and mindfulness treatment could adjust neural activity underlying social anxiety disorder (SAD) and exert therapeutic effects.
results_summary: The study suggests that psilocybin-assisted mindfulness interventions may modify cognitive processes linked to SAD, such as biased attention to threat, by modulating neural connectivity and increasing control over amygdala reactivity. Findings indicate potential therapeutic benefits for SAD patients who do not respond to conventional therapy.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals and patient samples (including those with social anxiety disorder).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between parental dispositional emotion regulation tendencies (both maladaptive and adaptive, including mindfulness) and youth mental health symptoms.
results_summary: The study found a small-to-moderate association between maladaptive parental emotion regulation and heightened youth mental health symptoms (r = 0.25), and a small negative association between adaptive parental emotion regulation (including mindfulness) and youth symptoms (r = -0.16). Effects were stronger when reported by the same informant.
population_specificity: Parents and their youth (N = 6399 for maladaptive ER analysis; N = 4241 for adaptive ER analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) and cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) in reducing burnout among anesthesiology trainees.
results_summary: The initial MBSR and CBT intervention was found unfeasible due to attitudinal and logistic challenges, but a modified "confessions session" model led to organizational changes associated with reduced resident burnout and improved well-being.
population_specificity: Anesthesiology residency trainees

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of various interventions, including mindfulness, in improving mental health among immigrant women during the perinatal period.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness interventions were among the approaches examined, but no explicit significant effects were reported for most interventions, including mindfulness. Home visit programs and asset-building mental health interventions showed more positive outcomes.
population_specificity: Immigrant women in the perinatal period (pregnancy and child-rearing stages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of mindfulness meditation as an adjunct to lifestyle interventions for weight management in women with breast cancer.
results_summary: Mindfulness meditation was perceived as feasible and acceptable for weight management, with a focus on wellness, flexible delivery, trusted advice, and peer-support enhancing its acceptability. Acupuncture was deemed too invasive.
population_specificity: Women who had received treatment for breast cancer, including a purposive sample of culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the literature on PTSD assessment scales and therapeutic approaches in patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: The study identified commonly used PTSD scales (CAPS, PCL-M, PCL-S, PCL-C) but noted heterogeneity in assessing additional psychiatric comorbidities and cognitive impairments. It emphasized the need for validated instruments in intervention studies for post-TBI PTSD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI) and PTSD, including civilian and military populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the Make It Training, a mindfulness-based e-mental health intervention, in reducing psychological distress among cancer patients compared to optimized treatment as usual (TAU-O).
results_summary: The study expects the Make It Training to be superior to TAU-O in reducing distress post-intervention (primary endpoint), with follow-up assessments at 3 and 6 months to evaluate sustained effects. The abstract does not provide final results but outlines a rigorous methodology to test the intervention's effectiveness.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 with a cancer diagnosis in the past 12 months, in curative treatment, and experiencing high psychological distress (Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale ≥13 for at least 1 week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of loving-kindness meditation (LKM) on employees' mindfulness, affect, altruism, and knowledge hiding behaviors.
results_summary: LKM significantly increased altruism and reduced negative affect, playing dumb, and evasive hiding, but did not significantly improve mindfulness, positive affect, or rationalized hiding.
population_specificity: 100 employees from a knowledge-based enterprise in China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current online programs, including mindfulness-based interventions, for promoting mental health and preventing mental disorders in medical students.
results_summary: One program showed significant immediate effects on mindfulness, empathy, and resilience, while two studies indicated strengthened coping strategies. However, most studies lacked control groups, and evidence of effectiveness was limited.
population_specificity: Medical students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of an online Parenting Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (PACT) course in improving emotional availability, parental mindfulness, and child quality of life in families of children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in parental non-intrusiveness, child involvement, parental mindfulness, and child quality of life (social wellbeing, acceptance, participation, and physical health). Effects persisted at a six-month follow-up, though no changes were observed in parent or child adjustment.
population_specificity: Families of children (2-10 years) with cerebral palsy.
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated, but assessments were conducted at baseline, post-intervention, and six-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based therapies for reducing anxiety in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients.
results_summary: The study found mixed results for mindfulness-based therapies in reducing anxiety in PD patients, with a stronger evidence base supporting cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). Other therapeutic approaches, including mindfulness, were under-researched.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease (PD) patients with anxiety.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary effects of integrating formal mindfulness meditation within an ACT-based approach (AMP) compared to CBT for improving function and other outcomes in Veterans with chronic pain.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so definitive results are not yet available, but it seeks to determine if formal mindfulness practice enhances ACT's effectiveness for chronic pain and provides data for a future full-scale RCT.
population_specificity: Veterans with chronic pain (N = 86)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a 6-week workplace mindfulness- and self-compassion-based intervention (MSCBI) versus a standard Workplace Stress Management Intervention on stress, burnout, immune function, self-compassion, and experiential avoidance.
results_summary: The MSCBI showed significant improvements in perceived stress, salivary Immunoglobulin A (sIgA), emotional exhaustion, self-compassion, and experiential avoidance compared to the control intervention, suggesting it may be more effective for work-related stress and burnout.
population_specificity: 24 employees of an automotive company.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors influencing adherence to mHealth apps, including those targeting mindfulness, and to quantify adherence scores for various health domains.
results_summary: The study found that personalization, reminders, user-friendly design, and personal support positively influenced adherence to mindfulness apps. Adherence scores for mHealth apps averaged 56.0% (SD 24.4%).
population_specificity: Users of mHealth apps targeting noncommunicable diseases, including mindfulness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and combined effect of aerobic exercise and mindfulness meditation, compared to mindfulness meditation alone and a control condition, on stress, anxiety, and depression in high-stress college-based young adults.
results_summary: The study compared the effects of aerobic exercise combined with mindfulness meditation versus mindfulness meditation alone and a control group, but specific results regarding the efficacy of mindfulness meditation were not detailed in the provided abstract.
population_specificity: High-stress college-based young adults (84.4% female, mean age 20.5 ± 2.7 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acceptability and feasibility of a yoga intervention compared to cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) for adolescents with depression, in preparation for a future trial testing yoga's non-inferiority to CBT.
results_summary: Both yoga and CBT interventions met most acceptability and feasibility targets, with participants showing decreased depression symptoms and increased self-compassion over time, though engagement in unstructured home practice was low.
population_specificity: Adolescents with elevated depression symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) on attention-related problems, hyperactivity-impulsivity, cardiac vagal control (CVC), and mood in children and adolescents with ADHD.
results_summary: The study found that one brief session of MBI slightly improved CVC but did not significantly enhance attention-related problems, hyperactivity-impulsivity, or mood in children with ADHD. The effects on omission errors were small and non-statistically significant, and no significant differences were observed in mood improvement between groups.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents (mean age 11.03, SD 2.78) with a clinical diagnosis of ADHD.
study_duration: Single session, with assessments at baseline, post-treatment, and 4-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a universal process-based CBT intervention, including mindfulness, in promoting positive mental health outcomes in early adolescents.
results_summary: The intervention was satisfactory to participants but did not show significantly superior growth rates in positive mental health, resilience, emotional literacy, or mindfulness compared to the control group at post-intervention or follow-up.
population_specificity: Early adolescents in elementary schools

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether food insecurity is associated with higher food addiction symptom endorsement in low-income female adults, using baseline data from studies on mindfulness-based interventions and observational research.
results_summary: The study found that food-insecure households had significantly higher food addiction symptoms compared to food-secure households, with a 21% increase in pregnant individuals and a 56% increase in caregivers. The results suggest a preliminary link between food insecurity and food addiction.
population_specificity: Low-income pregnant individuals with overweight or obesity (Study 1) and low-income female caregivers for children aged 8-10 (Study 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a brief mindfulness intervention on parent-child regulatory responding (via HRV) during pediatric venipuncture and assess the role of cognitive-affective factors like mindfulness, parent anxiety, and catastrophizing.
results_summary: The study found that HRV varied by procedural phase, but the mindfulness exercise did not consistently affect HRV in dyads. Positive synchrony was observed in dyads with high parental catastrophizing during the intervention's end, while nonsynchrony was otherwise prevalent.
population_specificity: 61 parent-child dyads (children aged 7-12 years) undergoing venipuncture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and prophylactic efficacy of a Comprehensive Ayurveda and mindfulness-based Yoga (CAY) regimen as an add-on to standard care for preventing COVID-19 and improving mental health in healthcare workers.
results_summary: The CAY group showed lower incidence of COVID-19 and influenza-like illness (ILI) events compared to the control group, though the difference was not statistically significant. The CAY group also demonstrated significant improvement in the health change domain of the SF-36 quality-of-life questionnaire.
population_specificity: Healthcare workers (HCWs) of both sexes in a tertiary care hospital in Delhi.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify structural neural correlates of the Mindfulness-Based Blood Pressure Reduction (MB-BP) program and assess potential correlations with clinical outcomes like interoception and depression.
results_summary: MB-BP participants showed increased interoception and decreased depressive symptoms compared to controls, with DTI data revealing significant group differences in white matter neural tracts linked to the limbic system and blood pressure. Changes in neural connectivity were associated with improvements in interoception and depression.
population_specificity: Adults with hypertension (subset of 14 MB-BP participants and 22 controls from a larger trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and acceptability of the 'Whitu' well-being app, which includes mindfulness modules, in improving emotional and mental well-being among young people.
results_summary: The study found that the Whitu app significantly improved emotional and mental well-being, self-compassion, sleep quality, and reduced stress and depression at 4 weeks, with sustained effects at 3 months. Anxiety symptoms also showed improvement, though initially non-significant at 4 weeks, becoming significant by 3 months.
population_specificity: New Zealand young people aged 16-30.
effective_dosage: Seven modules (one per day or as desired).
study_duration: 4 weeks (primary endpoint) with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the usability and efficacy of a coach-supported app-based CBT program (including mindfulness) for treating body dysmorphic disorder (BDD).
results_summary: The Perspectives app, which included mindfulness as a core component, significantly reduced BDD severity and improved secondary outcomes like insight, depression, and quality of life compared to a waitlist control, with medium to large effect sizes.
population_specificity: Adults (N = 80) with primary BDD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of online CBT and MBSR for people with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and determine if a history of recurrent depression moderates treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR was more effective than CBT for RA patients with a history of recurrent depression, though this was a post-hoc finding from a small subsample. The current trial seeks to validate these results with a larger sample and structured analysis.
population_specificity: Adults with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), specifically those with or without a history of recurrent depressive episodes.
study_duration: Post-treatment and 6-month follow-up (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how psychosocial factors, including mindfulness, influence pain interference and related outcomes in chronic pain patients over a one-year period.
results_summary: Patients with high psychosocial distress (PSP cluster) reported lower mindfulness levels and greater pain interference, loneliness, and reduced optimism compared to other clusters. Mindfulness was identified as a potential behavioral target for improving outcomes in this group.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic pain (n=94) during COVID-19-related social distancing.
study_duration: Observational follow-up over one year (April 2020 to June 2021)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of mindfulness interventions (MIs) on psychological outcomes in older adults (≥60 years) with chronic health conditions.
results_summary: The review found promising early evidence for MIs improving psychological outcomes, though current studies generally lack methodological rigor and have a high risk of bias. More randomized control trials are needed to strengthen the evidence base.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥60 years) with chronic health conditions, including chronic pain, stroke, type 2 diabetes, insomnia, cancer, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) with inference-based cognitive-behavioral therapy (I-CBT) and appraisal-based cognitive behavioral therapy (A-CBT) in treating OCD.
results_summary: MBSR significantly reduced general OCD severity and specific symptom dimensions, with outcomes similar to A-CBT. I-CBT showed greater improvement in overvalued ideation and higher remission rates compared to MBSR at mid-test.
population_specificity: 111 participants diagnosed with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of mindfulness (as part of the active comparator group) with other weight loss interventions (ROC, ROC+, and BWL) over 12 months of treatment and 12 months of follow-up.
results_summary: The active comparator (AC) group, which included mindfulness, showed substantially higher BMI at the end of treatment compared to ROC, ROC+, and BWL interventions, indicating less effectiveness for weight loss. No significant long-term differences in BMI reductions were noted between groups at 24 months.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 with a BMI of 25-45, predominantly female (81.6%) and White (61.9%).
study_duration: 12 months of treatment, with 12 months of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a live online mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (tele-MBCT) intervention for family caregivers of individuals with dementia.
results_summary: The tele-MBCT intervention showed significant pre-post improvements in self-compassion and coping strategies compared to the control group, with high participant satisfaction and feasibility.
population_specificity: Family caregivers of individuals with dementia (primarily female, mean age 60±13 years).
effective_dosage: Eight weekly live online sessions, with an average daily practice of 23.58±45.71 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a mindfulness-based intervention with an evidence-based psychoeducation program and treatment-as-usual for reducing caregiver burden, depression, anxiety, and improving positive caregiving experiences among Chinese family caregivers of frail older adults.
results_summary: The study will analyze the effects of mindfulness on caregiver burden, depression, anxiety, positive caregiving experience, spirituality, family conflict, and heart rate variability, with mediation effects explored through coping styles, experiential avoidance, and self-efficacy. A six-month follow-up will assess maintenance effects.
population_specificity: Chinese cross-generational caregivers of frail older adults with moderate to severe frailty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of an adapted mindfulness-based stress management program on perceived stress and emotional regulation in midwives.
results_summary: The intervention effectively reduced perceived stress and improved emotion regulation post-intervention, though the stress reduction effect was not sustained at the 3-month follow-up. Emotion regulation improvements remained significant at follow-up.
population_specificity: Midwives working in general hospitals in Zanjan, Iran.
effective_dosage: 8-week adapted mindfulness-based stress management program (derived from Kabat-Zinn's MBSR program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how mindfulness training reduces error hiding in hospital settings by promoting authentic functioning.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness training decreased error hiding by fostering a receptive self-view and authentic functioning, which encourages openness to both positive and negative self-information. These effects were confirmed through quantitative and qualitative analyses.
population_specificity: Hospital staff in a randomized control trial (mindfulness training vs. active control group vs. waitlist control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of third-wave interventions like mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) and acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) for improving hearing-related distress and psychological well-being in people with audiological problems.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to recommend third-wave interventions for improving hearing-related distress or psychological well-being in people with audiological problems, though there was some short-term evidence for ACT and MBIs in tinnitus patients. The findings were limited by poor-to-moderate methodological quality and small sample sizes.
population_specificity: People with audiological problems, particularly tinnitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) in patients with non-cardiac chest pain and assess its impact on anxiety, depression, and mindfulness.
results_summary: The study found that MBCT led to a significant reduction in general anxiety and improved mindfulness, with a trend toward better chest pain symptoms, though the sample size was small and not statistically powered.
population_specificity: Patients with persistent non-cardiac chest pain (mean age 54.2 years, 68% women).
effective_dosage: 2-hour weekly online guided sessions for 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness training (MBSR) enhances innate immune responsivity, measured by stimulated IL-6 production, in lonely older adults.
results_summary: Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) significantly increased stimulated IL-6 production compared to the control intervention (HEP) both post-intervention and at 3-month follow-up, suggesting improved innate immunocompetence. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Lonely older adults aged 65-85 years (N=190).
effective_dosage: 8-week Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) program (specific session frequency/duration not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: 8 weeks, with follow-up at 3 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based interventions (MBI) reduce depression and trait anxiety while increasing mindfulness, self-compassion, and related behaviors, and whether self-compassionate behaviors moderate the effect of mindful behaviors on mood.
results_summary: The study found that MBI may decrease depression and trait anxiety while increasing trait mindfulness, self-compassion, and related behaviors, with self-compassionate behaviors potentially moderating the effect of mindful behaviors on mood.
population_specificity: Patients with depression and/or anxiety.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of body scan meditation as a sole mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) and its impact on health-related outcomes.
results_summary: Body scan meditation had a small effect on mindfulness compared to passive control, with low attrition rates in long-term interventions. However, the quality of studies was low, heterogeneity was high, and body scan alone was not effective enough to improve health-related outcomes.
population_specificity: No population restriction (generalized across populations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of loving-kindness and compassion meditation (LKCM) in improving life satisfaction through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: LKCM significantly enhanced life satisfaction in pre-post designs but showed no significant effect in randomized controlled trials. The effects varied based on control group type, with LKCM outperforming waitlist conditions but not active controls.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of 23 empirical studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) and acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) on positive psychology, quality of life, and psychological complications in newly diagnosed head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results for MBSR, but it assessed outcomes like posttraumatic growth, hope, optimism, depression, anxiety, and quality of life across three time points.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed head and neck cancer patients who had undergone surgery or had not yet received treatment.
effective_dosage: Eight modules over eight weeks (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and feasibility of a virtual mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) in reducing burnout and improving performance among neurosurgeons.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in perceived stress, emotional exhaustion, mindfulness skills, self-compassion, resilience, and choice response times. All participants who completed the post-intervention assessment recommended the course and found it relevant to their surgical practice.
population_specificity: Practicing neurosurgeons (attendings, residents, interns) from 9 neurosurgical centers, mean age 30.3 years.
effective_dosage: 8 weeks of 90-minute MBI classes with suggested daily practice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of a brief contextual behavioral intervention, based on Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) and Functional Analytic Psychotherapy (FAP), in improving psychological well-being among secondary school students.
results_summary: The intervention showed significant differences between groups in distress and significant interaction effects for life satisfaction, psychological flexibility, and mindfulness. Greater benefits were observed for girls than boys.
population_specificity: Secondary school students aged 17-19 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short- and long-term effects of two mindfulness training programs on students' stress and well-being.
results_summary: Psychological distress increased less in the intervention groups than in the control group post-intervention, but no differences were found at 4-month follow-up. Participants who continued mindfulness practice at least twice weekly reported lower stress levels.
population_specificity: Undergraduate students of medicine, dentistry, psychology, and logopaedics at the University of Helsinki.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of various psychosocial therapies, including mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), in relieving cancer-related fatigue (CRF) in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR was the most effective psychosocial intervention for reducing CRF in cancer patients, with the highest standardized mean difference (SMD = -1.23) and surface under the cumulative ranking curve (SUCRA = 83.33%). It outperformed other therapies like psychoeducation and cognitive-behavioral therapy.
population_specificity: Adult cancer patients (≥18 years) regardless of cancer stage or current treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize the indirect effects of mindful attention, decentering, and acceptance as mediators in acceptance and mindfulness-based therapies for anxiety and depression.
results_summary: The study found a small to medium pooled mediating effect (r = 0.145) of mindful attention, decentering, and acceptance on anxiety and depression, with correlation-based mediation approaches showing significant effects, while causal time-lag analyses did not. Mediator specificity could not be established.
population_specificity: Individuals with anxiety and depression (based on randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Mindfulness-Based Therapy for Insomnia (MBTI) and a sleep hygiene education and exercise program (SHEEP) on sleep macroarchitecture and microarchitecture.
results_summary: Both MBTI and SHEEP improved self-reported sleep quality, with MBTI increasing N2 sleep and SHEEP increasing N3 sleep. No significant differences were found in N1, REM, or sleep fragmentation, but SHEEP showed decreased higher frequency non-REM EEG power.
population_specificity: 48 MBTI and 46 SHEEP participants with insomnia.
effective_dosage: 8 weekly 2-hour group sessions and daily practice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of third-wave psychotherapies, including mindfulness-based approaches (MBSR and MBCT), for addressing psychological difficulties in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: MBSR and MBCT showed potential benefits for addressing psychological difficulties in MS patients up to three months post-intervention, though MS-specific adaptations may be needed. Limited evidence was found for DBT and ACT, requiring further research.
population_specificity: Adults with multiple sclerosis (MS) experiencing psychological difficulties.
study_duration: Up to three months post-intervention (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a predictive index from baseline patient characteristics to determine which individuals are most likely to benefit from mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) compared to health education.
results_summary: The study found that individuals who improved following MBSR were more likely to be younger, female, with lower psychological symptom severity, and less likely to have depression or be taking SSRIs. The predictive index had a moderate effect size (0.46).
population_specificity: Older adults (103 participants) with anxiety and/or depressive disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of feasible treatments, including mindfulness, for patients with opioid use disorder (OUD) and comorbid chronic pain.
results_summary: Mindfulness showed promising but inconclusive results, with a discrete effect on improving negative affect but not pain. Data were limited, with fewer than two RCTs of low risk of bias.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic pain and comorbid opioid use disorder (OUD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a 30-day mindfulness intervention on stress and cognitive performance in Danish employees using a crowdsourcing approach.
results_summary: The mindfulness group showed significant improvements in sustained attention, working memory capacity, and perceived stress (p < .001). There was also a significant correlation between app usage and improved cognitive and stress scores.
population_specificity: 623 healthy volunteers from Danish companies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of an online mindfulness induction on state mindfulness and state stress in university students with versus without a history of nonsuicidal self-injury (NSSI).
results_summary: The study investigated whether brief mindfulness inductions could buffer acute stress differently in students with a history of NSSI compared to those without, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Canadian university students with and without a history of nonsuicidal self-injury (NSSI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize existing literature on VR-based mindfulness applications for managing chronic pain in adults.
results_summary: The review found that VR-based mindfulness may improve chronic pain management, with benefits in physical and mental health, treatment engagement, and usability, though weak study designs and small sample sizes limited conclusions.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of psychological interventions, including mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT), in reducing depression and anxiety in people with dementia or mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found very few data and very low-certainty evidence on MBCT, making it unable to draw any conclusions about its effectiveness for the studied population.
population_specificity: People with dementia or mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and describe potential occupational therapy interventions, including mindfulness-based stress reduction therapies, for poststroke fatigue.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence for occupational therapy interventions targeting poststroke fatigue, with mindfulness-based stress reduction being one of the approaches explored. Commonly used outcome measures included the Fatigue Severity Scale and the Mental Fatigue Scale.
population_specificity: Stroke and traumatic brain injury patients in outpatient, inpatient, and community settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility of using mindfulness, alongside CBT and biofeedback, as part of a multidisciplinary approach to manage paroxysmal dyskinesia (PD) episodes.
results_summary: The study observed reductions in galvanic skin response (GSR) volatility associated with PD episodes following behavioral interventions, suggesting mindfulness and biofeedback may help manage PD symptoms. The paper highlights the potential of GSR biofeedback as an adjunct to mindfulness and CBT in PD treatment.
population_specificity: A 50-year-old male with paroxysmal dyskinesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mindfulness yoga versus conventional stretching exercises on symptom management and HRQOL in Parkinson's disease patients, while examining the mediating roles of anxiety and depression.
results_summary: Yoga significantly improved nonmotor and motor symptoms compared to stretching, with reduced anxiety and depression mediating these positive effects on HRQOL. The study concluded that mindfulness yoga is superior to stretching for symptom relief in PD patients.
population_specificity: 138 adults with Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of mindfulness-based supportive therapy (MBST) in reducing suffering among patients with advanced cancer.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in overall suffering scores in the MBST group compared to the control group, suggesting MBST can promote positive psychosocial outcomes in advanced cancer patients.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced cancer (overall suffering score ≥4/10 based on the Suffering Pictogram).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether exposure to traumatic events (ETE) is related to craving via trauma symptoms and how trait mindfulness might attenuate this association among women in substance use disorder (SUD) treatment.
results_summary: The study found that low levels of acting with awareness (a facet of mindfulness) may worsen trauma symptoms after ETE, leading to increased craving. Despite a small moderating effect size, acting with awareness may have clinical significance due to the prevalence of trauma symptoms in this population.
population_specificity: Women (N=245) in SUD treatment, aged 18-65, predominantly Hispanic (58.5%), with a mean age of 32.2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a mindfulness stress management intervention on fear of recurrence and quality of life among female cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found that 12 weeks of mindfulness stress intervention effectively reduced fear of recurrence symptoms in female cancer survivors.
population_specificity: Female cancer survivors (60 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence levels, study characteristics, and outcomes of nonpharmacologic complementary and integrative medicine (CIM) interventions, including mindfulness, in rehabilitation for individuals with traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: The study found that 11% of the included studies examined meditation/mindfulness/relaxation, with 97% of all studies reporting overall positive benefits of CIM interventions. However, rigorous experimental designs, including RCTs, are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Individuals with traumatic brain injury (TBI) of any severity and age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of mindfulness-based breathing and music therapy on stress, work-related strain, and psychological well-being levels of nurses caring for COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based breathing and music therapy significantly reduced stress and work-related strain while increasing psychological well-being in nurses. The control group showed no significant changes in these measures.
population_specificity: Nurses providing care for COVID-19 patients in a university hospital in Turkey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the outcomes and mechanisms of change in a 4-session ACT training program designed to reduce psychological distress among healthcare staff.
results_summary: The ACT intervention significantly reduced symptoms of psychological distress and, to a lesser extent, burnout, with improvements mediated by enhanced mindfulness skills and values-based behavior. Nearly half of participants showed reliable improvements in distress, with a subset meeting criteria for clinically significant change.
population_specificity: Healthcare staff (n = 98) from a healthcare organization.
effective_dosage: 4-session ACT training program (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the personal experiences of women undergoing cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and mindfulness-based therapy (MBT) for low sexual desire.
results_summary: Both CBT and MBT were found effective in improving women's sexual desire, but the study focused more on participants' personal experiences rather than quantitative outcomes.
population_specificity: 51 cis-women with low sexual desire.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the claim that inflammation may provoke present-focused decision making and impulsivity, assessing challenges in the existing literature.
results_summary: The study highlights three key challenges to the inflammation-impulsivity link: (1) imprecise definitions of impulsivity, (2) reverse causality, and (3) lack of causal evidence, suggesting areas for future research improvement.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract discusses preclinical models and clinical interventions broadly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a remote, online, group-based mindfulness intervention could produce measurable benefits during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The intervention showed significant benefits for mindfulness, rumination, worry, mood, stress, anxiety, three aspects of psychological wellbeing, and physical activity, with an average effect size of 0.48. No significant effect was observed for depression.
population_specificity: 111 college students (58 in the intervention group, 53 in a waitlist control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of mindfulness-based interventions for smoking cessation and their impact on mental health outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no clear benefit of mindfulness-based interventions for increasing smoking quit rates or improving mental health and well-being compared to other treatments or no treatment. The evidence was of low certainty due to risk of bias, inconsistency, and imprecision.
population_specificity: Adults who smoke, primarily recruited from the community (majority of studies conducted in the USA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether workplace mindfulness influences stress appraisal and affect, and if mindfulness training enhances these effects.
results_summary: The studies found that mindfulness positively influenced daily challenge appraisal (linked to positive affect) and reduced threat appraisal (linked to negative affect). Mindfulness training increased daily mindfulness, which in turn improved appraisal and affect.
population_specificity: Employees (58 in Study 1, 69 in Study 2)
study_duration: 5 working days (Study 1), duration not specified for Study 2

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if app-based mindfulness training (MT) could reduce worry and improve sleep in individuals with worry-related sleep disturbances, while examining underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: App-based MT significantly reduced worry-related sleep disturbances (27% reduction) compared to treatment as usual (6% reduction), mediated by decreased worry and improved nonreactivity. No significant differences in total sleep time or efficiency were found, but benefits were maintained at 4 months.
population_specificity: Individuals reporting worry interfering with sleep (n = 80, split into two groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize data on the prevalence and treatment of depressive symptoms among homeless people, including the potential role of mindfulness as a therapeutic intervention.
results_summary: The study found that therapeutic interventions, including mindfulness, demonstrated substantial improvement in quality of life and reduction in depressive symptoms among homeless people, though specific data on mindfulness alone was limited.
population_specificity: Homeless individuals with depressive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of mindfulness-based meditation as a non-pharmacological intervention for alleviating painful symptoms in joint diseases, particularly osteoarthritis, through autonomic nervous system modulation.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness-based meditation, along with other non-pharmacological interventions like vagus nerve stimulation and exercise, shows promise in reducing painful symptoms of joint diseases, potentially mediated by the autonomic nervous system. However, research on this topic is still limited.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic pain states, particularly osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding acceptance training to mindfulness monitoring improves mental health outcomes (anxiety and depression) in pregnant individuals compared to monitoring alone or an active control.
results_summary: Monitoring with an emphasis on acceptance training significantly reduced anxiety and depression symptoms and improved self-efficacy in managing depression/distress compared to monitoring alone and the control group. Monitoring alone showed a downward trend in anxiety scores and improved self-efficacy in managing anger/irritation.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals with depressive or anxious symptoms (N = 149).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and health outcomes of weight-neutral interventions, including mindfulness, in adolescents with overweight/obesity.
results_summary: Mindfulness interventions showed mixed results; one study reported no change in mindfulness, while another reported increased intuitive eating with guided imagery. Short-term feasibility and acceptability were demonstrated, but data on efficacy were limited.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 10-24 years with overweight/obesity, including those at risk of type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of short session-introducing mindfulness interventions on symptomatic outcomes and therapeutic alliance in individual psychotherapy for children and adolescents.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that mindfulness interventions will improve symptomatic outcomes and therapeutic alliance more than relaxation or no interventions, and that mindfulness may moderate the relationship between therapeutic alliance and symptomatic outcomes. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 11-19 with primary diagnoses of depressive, anxiety, or hyperkinetic disorders.
effective_dosage: Not specified (short session-introducing interventions at the beginning of 24 therapy sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the history and evolution of Morita therapy (MT) and examine its adaptations, including comparisons to mindfulness.
results_summary: The abstract notes that MT's fundamental theory was refined and adapted to modern conditions, enabling comparisons with mindfulness, but does not provide specific findings on mindfulness itself. Further work is suggested to evaluate MT's effectiveness from a clinical epidemiological perspective.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on MT's historical and theoretical evolution).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of yoga as a complementary therapy for reducing pain, disability, and mood symptoms in adults with chronic nonspecific neck pain (CNNP).
results_summary: The review found that supervised yoga programs may reduce pain intensity, disability, and mood symptoms in CNNP patients, with some evidence of improved cervical range of motion and quality of life. However, evidence of yoga's superiority to other exercise-based practices was inconsistent, and adverse effects were rare and minor.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic nonspecific neck pain (CNNP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an app-based intervention, which included mindfulness as a secondary outcome, to reduce addictive behaviors in vocational school students.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding mindfulness, as the study is a protocol and outcomes are yet to be measured.
population_specificity: Vocational school students in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the morphologic variants and mimics of low-grade endometrioid adenocarcinoma (ECa) to improve diagnostic accuracy and treatment strategies.
results_summary: The study reviewed various morphologic variants of low-grade ECa, discussing their histologic, immunohistochemical, and molecular features, and emphasized the importance of recognizing low-grade cytologic features to distinguish ECa from high-grade mimics.
population_specificity: Pathologists and clinicians diagnosing endometrioid adenocarcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) could improve cognitive outcomes, specifically memory-related impairments, in breast cancer survivors who had undergone chemotherapy.
results_summary: MBSR participants showed a significant reduction in subjective memory failures (prospective and retrospective) at 2 weeks post-intervention, but no effects were observed on objective cognitive assessments. The study suggests MBSR may help mitigate subjective memory difficulties in this population.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors with neuropathic pain who had received chemotherapy.
study_duration: 3 months (assessments at baseline, 2 weeks, and 3 months post-MBSR)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of mindfulness and pelvic floor physical therapy (PFPT) in treating or managing chronic pelvic pain (CPP) in women.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness combined with PFPT significantly reduced pain catastrophizing and improved sexual function during follow-up, suggesting a multidisciplinary approach may be beneficial for CPP management.
population_specificity: Women with chronic pelvic pain (CPP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze psychological factors influencing diabetic neuropathy (DN) pain and evaluate the impact of mindfulness-based stress reduction on DN pain severity.
results_summary: A retrospective study found a correlation between mindfulness-based stress reduction and improvement in DN pain severity. The review also highlighted the beneficial impact of psychotherapeutic modalities, including mindfulness, on DN pain.
population_specificity: Patients with painful diabetic neuropathy (DN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Internet-based psychological interventions, including mindfulness therapy, in reducing depressive and anxiety symptoms among pregnant women.
results_summary: Mindfulness therapy showed beneficial effects in improving depressive symptoms (g = -0.62) among pregnant women, with small to moderate effect sizes. However, there was insufficient evidence for its impact on fear of childbirth and stress symptoms.
population_specificity: Pregnant women from more than 23 countries (n = 3894).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of a 6-week mindfulness-based stress management program (FOCUS) in reducing caregiver burden for allogeneic HCT caregivers and its impact on patient health outcomes.
results_summary: Recruitment is ongoing; no results are reported yet. The study hypothesizes that FOCUS will reduce caregiver burden and improve patient health outcomes compared to other conditions.
population_specificity: Caregivers of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HCT) cancer patients.
effective_dosage: 6-week weekly individual treatment sessions and brief daily momentary interventions/messages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy could reduce neural reactivity linked to depression relapse and compare its prophylactic effects to Cognitive Therapy with a Well-Being focus.
results_summary: The study found that Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy was associated with reduced activation in the left lateral prefrontal cortex, which was linked to treatment-related prophylaxis. However, somatosensory deactivation remained a static biomarker of relapse, unaffected by treatment.
population_specificity: Remitted depressed outpatients (N = 85) with a history of Major Depressive Disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the effectiveness of a school-based mindfulness intervention for depressive symptoms in adolescents varies based on individual characteristics like executive functions, rumination, and emotion regulation.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based intervention was more effective for adolescents with high catastrophizing, high acceptance, and low executive functions, though sex differences were noted. The results are preliminary due to the exploratory nature of the study and lack of corrections for multiple testing.
population_specificity: Adolescents (6th-8th grade, 68.4% female) with at least mild depressive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness and acceptance-based interventions (MABIs) for depression symptoms in Black Americans.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a moderate effect of MABIs on depression symptoms (g = 0.48), with similar effects across majority and predominantly Black participant subsets. Effects were influenced by sample and intervention characteristics, showing stronger support for adult samples than youth.
population_specificity: Black Americans (70% average proportion across studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a technology-supported mindfulness intervention integrated into diabetes care on psychological and biobehavioral outcomes in veterans with diabetes.
results_summary: The mindfulness intervention showed stronger distal effects on diabetes distress compared to the control group, particularly when baseline HbA1C was <8.5%. It also improved general dietary behaviors, but other secondary outcomes like diabetes self-efficacy, PTSD, depression, and HbA1C improved in both groups without significant intervention effects.
population_specificity: US military veterans with type 1 or 2 diabetes (N=132).
effective_dosage: One initial mindfulness session integrated into DSMES, one booster session, and 24 weeks of home practice supported by a mobile app.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of decentering and related variables in the efficacy of Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) compared to relaxation group therapy (RGT) and treatment as usual (TAU) for preventing depression relapse.
results_summary: MBCT prevented symptom gains in depression compared to RGT and TAU, and gains in decentering predicted reductions in depression for MBCT and TAU. Increased decentering was associated with lower relapse rates, though results were exploratory due to small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Formerly depressed individuals (N = 227).
study_duration: Pre-, mid-, and posttreatment assessments; relapse monitored for 12 months posttreatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of online mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) for improving mental health in patients with physical health conditions.
results_summary: Online MBIs were effective in improving depression, anxiety, stress, and mindfulness in patients with physical conditions, but no significant effects were found on well-being.
population_specificity: Patients with physical health conditions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness (as part of meditation interventions) in improving sustained attention in children and adolescents.
results_summary: Mindfulness training showed rather consistent positive effects on selective attention, though the overall evidence for transfer to other cognitive, behavioral, and academic outcomes was very weak. The effects were considered preliminary and in need of replication with greater methodological rigor.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 3-18 years

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the mechanisms of action, specifically self-compassion and self-criticism, underlying the therapeutic effects of Mindfulness-Based Trauma Recovery for Refugees (MBTR-R) on trauma recovery in refugees and asylum-seekers.
results_summary: MBTR-R significantly increased self-compassion and reduced self-criticism, with changes in self-criticism mediating improvements in depression and PTSD, and changes in self-compassion mediating improvements in PTSD. The intervention showed therapeutic efficacy compared to wait-list controls.
population_specificity: 158 traumatized and chronically stressed asylum-seekers (46% female) in an urban post-displacement setting in the Middle East.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess current loneliness interventions, including mindful meditation, for informal caregivers to inform the development of effective therapies to improve their quality of life.
results_summary: Mindful meditation was one of five intervention types identified, but most interventions, including mindfulness, had methodological limitations and demonstrated small effect sizes. Caregivers may benefit from interventions that expand their social network to improve emotional regulation and role understanding.
population_specificity: Informal caregivers, primarily spouses, of persons with dementia and other disabling conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Mentalizing Imagery Therapy (MIT) with caregiver skills training via a smartphone app could reduce stress and insomnia in family dementia caregivers more effectively than skills training alone.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a trial to assess MIT's superiority in reducing caregiver stress and insomnia, as well as exploring passive smartphone data for behavioral markers predicting health outcomes, but results are not yet reported.
population_specificity: Family dementia caregivers aged 60 years or older.
