study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness meditation improves doctors' mindfulness, patient safety culture, patient safety competency, and reduces adverse events.
results_summary: Mindfulness meditation significantly increased mindfulness, patient safety culture, and competency in doctors, while reducing adverse events compared to the control group. The control group showed no significant changes in these variables.
population_specificity: 91 doctors from a hospital in China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a mindfulness-based self-help internet intervention and a CBT-based self-help internet intervention versus a waiting list control in reducing cannabis use among frequent cannabis users.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial design to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness- and CBT-based interventions in reducing cannabis use, with primary and secondary outcomes measured at multiple time points, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Frequent cannabis users

study_goal: To identify mindfulness-based interventions and evaluate their effect on the psychological well-being of nurses.
results_summary: Ten out of eleven studies demonstrated a positive impact of mindfulness-based interventions on nurses' psychological well-being, including improvements in stress, depression, anxiety, burnout, resilience, quality of life, self-compassion, happiness, and mindfulness levels.
population_specificity: Nurses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of the Meditation-Based Lifestyle Modification (MBLM) program, a second-generation mindfulness-based intervention, in reducing depressive symptoms in outpatients with mild to moderate depression.
results_summary: The MBLM program showed a greater reduction in depressive symptoms compared to the control group, with statistically significant results (p < .001). The study also noted beneficial effects at a 6-month follow-up, suggesting sustained efficacy.
population_specificity: Outpatients with mild to moderate depression (n=81).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of mindfulness-based practices as a complementary alternative medicine (CAM) in the treatment of insomnia disorder.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based practices, along with other CAMs, proved supportive in treating insomnia disorder, though accessibility and qualified facilitators remain limitations.
population_specificity: Patients with insomnia disorder, including chronic, short-term, and other subtypes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Mindfulness-based therapies (MBTs) in improving the quality of life for cancer patients and their relatives, focusing on methodological quality, MBT types, and study populations.
results_summary: MBTs demonstrated efficacy in 25 out of 30 included RCTs, though findings were limited by study heterogeneity. Methodological quality was acceptable, but variability in measures and populations reduced generalizability.
population_specificity: Primarily females diagnosed with breast cancer in English-speaking countries outside Europe; one study included relatives.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a therapeutic yoga program, incorporating mindfulness-based practices, could enhance the effects of transdiagnostic group CBT for depression or anxiety.
results_summary: CBT + Yoga showed significantly lower depressive and anxiety symptoms post-intervention compared to CBT alone, with sustained reductions in depressive symptoms over three months and more rapid symptom improvement.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with depression or anxiety in a regional primary mental healthcare service (n = 59).
study_duration: Post-intervention and three-month follow-up (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enhanced mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR+) modifies the relationship between quantitative sensory testing (QST) profiles and migraine symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR+ modified the linear combination of migraine symptoms related to QST, suggesting a selective relationship between QST and pain symptoms. No differences in QST ratings were observed between migraine patients and healthy controls.
population_specificity: Episodic migraine patients (n = 103) and healthy control subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between mindfulness and glycemia in adolescents with type 1 diabetes (T1D) and evaluate potential mediation by ingestive behaviors and impulsivity.
results_summary: Increased mindfulness was associated with lower HbA1c levels, but no significant mediation by ingestive behaviors or impulsivity was found. No statistically significant associations were observed between mindfulness and continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) metrics.
population_specificity: Adolescents (mean age 14.9 years) with type 1 diabetes and suboptimal glycemia, predominantly non-Hispanic white (83.6%), 50.7% female, and 73.0% using insulin pumps.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a brief Mindfulness-Based Intervention (bMBI) on endometriosis-related pain and psychological well-being in women with deep endometriosis who remained symptomatic despite conventional medical treatment.
results_summary: The study found that bMBI significantly improved pain unpleasantness and psychological well-being compared to standard medical treatment alone. The intervention showed promise for managing endometriosis-related pain and enhancing mental health.
population_specificity: Women with deep endometriosis who remained symptomatic despite conventional medical treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and current measures of mental health apps (MHAs) for bipolar disorder (BD), including mindfulness-related outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that MHAs for BD, including mindfulness measures, showed varied effectiveness with low adherence rates and usability challenges. Mindfulness was assessed using the Mindfulness Attention Awareness Scale in one study, but broader efficacy was limited by confounding factors.
population_specificity: 435 participants, 343 with BD type I or II (mean age 37 years, male to female ratio 137:206).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mentalizing Imagery Therapy (MIT), which incorporates mindfulness and guided imagery, could reduce depression symptoms and improve positive psychological traits in family caregivers of dementia patients more effectively than a support group, while also examining associated changes in brain connectivity.
results_summary: MIT significantly improved depression, anxiety, mindfulness, self-compassion, and well-being compared to the support group, with moderate to large effect sizes. Neuroimaging showed increased dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) connectivity, which correlated with improved mindfulness and reduced depression, but no change in subgenual anterior cingulate cortex (sgACC) connectivity.
population_specificity: Family caregivers of patients with dementia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of mental health interventions, including mindfulness recordings, on COVID-19-related mental health challenges in non-hospitalized or non-quarantined individuals.
results_summary: Among the trials reviewed, mindfulness recordings were minimally adapted or not specifically adapted for COVID-19, and these trials had high risk of bias and reporting concerns. No specific efficacy data for mindfulness were highlighted in the well-conducted trials.
population_specificity: Children, adolescents, and adults not quarantined or undergoing treatment due to COVID-19 infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the motivation behind and subjective health impacts of Bahá'í fasting, particularly its effects on mindfulness and well-being.
results_summary: The study found that Bahá'í fasting increased mindfulness and well-being while reducing stress, anxiety, and fatigue, with some effects lasting three months post-fast. Behavioral changes, self-efficacy, and inner freedom were also reported.
population_specificity: Bahá'í volunteers (n = 146 survey respondents, n = 23 interview participants).
study_duration: 19 days (fasting period), with follow-up assessments up to three months post-fast.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on mediators, moderators, and implementation factors of school-based mindfulness training (SBMT) and propose a conceptual model for future research.
results_summary: The study found mixed results for moderators of SBMT, evidence that increased mindfulness skills and reduced cognitive reactivity and self-criticism improved outcomes, and assessed implementation factors in 25 studies. The current evidence is limited, and recommendations for future research were made.
population_specificity: Young people in universal school-based settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) in managing symptoms of complicated perinatal grief.
results_summary: Both CBT and MBIs showed favorable reductions in perinatal grief symptoms, depression, and posttraumatic stress, but a direct comparison was limited due to study heterogeneity and small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Bereaved parents experiencing perinatal grief (681 participants across 8 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of mindfulness and psychotherapy in managing depression alongside cancer pain in patients on long-term opioid therapy.
results_summary: The study recommends mindfulness and psychotherapy for patients with significant depression and cancer pain, suggesting it as a beneficial intervention alongside medication for moderate to severe symptoms.
population_specificity: Cancer patients on long-term opioid therapy with significant depression and chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of an 18-week mindfulness curriculum on emotion processing in children, comparing it to active and passive control groups.
results_summary: Mindfulness training in pre-adolescents enhanced emotional non-reactivity to negative distractors, with some effects being culturally sensitive. Changes in P3b latencies and LPP mean amplitudes were observed, particularly for Japanese faces, but not for Caucasian faces.
population_specificity: Vietnamese children aged 7-11 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) generalizes to everyday social stress situations and to explore the role of cognitive reappraisal and acceptance as emotion regulation mechanisms.
results_summary: MBSR reduced self-reported stress through cognitive reappraisal and acceptance when regulating self but not others' distress. Brain activation increased for regulating own and others' emotions, though similar effects were seen in the reading intervention for self-regulation. No distant generalization effects on socio-emotional functioning were found.
population_specificity: 68 participants in a randomized controlled trial (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) as an intervention for reducing symptoms in patients with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
results_summary: MBSR significantly reduced PTSD symptoms compared to control conditions, showing a moderately positive effect (g = 0.46, 95% CI: 0.31-0.62, p < 0.001). The effect was consistent across different causes of PTSD, indicating MBSR's broad applicability for symptom management.
population_specificity: Patients with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) from various causes (n = 768).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare and rank the efficacy of non-pharmacological interventions, including mindfulness-based intervention, on depression, anxiety, quality of life, and caregiver burden for informal caregivers of people with dementia.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based intervention might reduce depression in informal caregivers of people with dementia, but it did not show significant effects on anxiety, quality of life, or caregiver burden.
population_specificity: Informal caregivers of community-dwelling people with dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of mindfulness as part of a holistic management approach for post-acute COVID-19 sequelae.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness, alongside other interventions like nutrition and physical therapy, may help in early detection and prevention of long-term systemic damage from COVID-19. However, specific efficacy data on mindfulness alone is not detailed.
population_specificity: Adult populations with post-acute COVID-19 sequelae.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a yoga-based intervention package, including mindfulness meditation, in reducing behavioral problems among grade 8 school children in a post-conflict setting.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced emotional and peer problems in students, improved prosocial behavior according to teachers, and showed positive effects on school achievements, family dynamics, and individual health. Control group comparisons confirmed these benefits.
population_specificity: Grade 8 school children (early adolescents) in Jaffna Province, Sri Lanka, a post-conflict region.
effective_dosage: Mindfulness meditation for 5-6 minutes, along with other yoga-based practices (slow breathing for 5-6 minutes and Surya-namaskaram for 6-8 minutes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether trait mindfulness moderates the links between attachment insecurity and maladaptive sexual motives.
results_summary: Higher levels of the acting with awareness facet of trait mindfulness eliminated the links between attachment anxiety and maladaptive sexual motives (e.g., sex to cope and affirm the self). However, mindfulness increased maladaptive sexual motives in individuals with attachment avoidance.
population_specificity: 194 participants with measures of trait mindfulness, general sexual motivations, and attachment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the applicability and effectiveness of meditation-based therapies for managing chronic low back pain (CLBP).
results_summary: Meditation-based therapies significantly reduced CLBP pain intensity and bothersomeness and improved quality of life compared to nonmeditation therapies. The results were statistically significant and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic low back pain (1,153 patients across 12 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Resilience Training (RT), a brief, group-based intervention incorporating mindfulness, in reducing psychopathology symptoms and improving resilience in at-risk college students.
results_summary: RT participants showed significant reductions in psychotic experiences, distress, depression, and anxiety, along with improvements in resilience, mindfulness, self-compassion, and positive affect compared to the waitlist control group. The effects were sustained, suggesting potential long-term benefits.
population_specificity: College students with mildly elevated depressive or subclinical psychotic symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Mindfulness-Oriented Recovery Enhancement (MORE) in reducing opioid misuse and chronic pain symptoms among adults receiving long-term opioid therapy.
results_summary: The MORE intervention significantly reduced opioid misuse, pain severity, and pain-related functional interference compared to supportive psychotherapy, with sustained improvements over 9 months. Participants in the MORE group also showed greater reductions in opioid dosing, emotional distress, and opioid craving.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic pain receiving long-term opioid therapy who were misusing opioid medications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on sleep-wake disturbances in adults with cancer and evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction as a treatment option.
results_summary: The study found growing evidence supporting mindfulness-based stress reduction to diminish sleep-wake disturbances in cancer patients, alongside other interventions like cognitive behavioral therapy and exercise.
population_specificity: Adults with cancer experiencing sleep-wake disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Conflict Analysis (CA) versus mindfulness as a control in improving Whole Health outcomes among veterans in inpatient substance recovery care.
results_summary: Mindfulness was used as a control and showed some benefits, but CA demonstrated significant Whole Health advantages. Participant and clinician evaluations suggested mindfulness could still be personally relevant and meaningful, though CA was more effective.
population_specificity: Veterans in a rural northern New England VA inpatient substance recovery unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of electronic health, mindfulness-based interventions (eHealth-MBIs) on anxiety, depression, mindfulness, and quality of life among cancer patients/survivors.
results_summary: The eHealth-MBIs showed small but significant improvements in anxiety and depression, with short-term benefits for quality of life and mindfulness. The overall quality of evidence was rated as low for primary outcomes and very low for secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Cancer patients and survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether brief breath counting (mindfulness) reduces stress-induced alcohol cravings more effectively than simple distraction (cross counting).
results_summary: The study found that brief breath counting attenuated stress-induced increases in alcohol cravings, but it remains unclear whether this effect was due to increased mindfulness or mere distraction.
population_specificity: University students from England and the United States who were young adult alcohol users.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize the relationship between mindfulness and functional connectivity in brain networks, focusing on trait mindfulness and mindfulness meditation interventions.
results_summary: Mindfulness was associated with functional connectivity changes in the default mode, frontoparietal, and salience networks, including increased connectivity linked to attention control and emotion regulation, and decreased connectivity related to self-awareness and pain relief.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cost-effectiveness of mindfulness meditation (MAP-I) versus cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) in treating insomnia among Alzheimer's disease caregivers.
results_summary: MAP-I was found to be significantly more cost-effective than CBT-I, with per-participant savings of 53% for individual and 30% for group delivery. Instructor in-class time was the highest cost component for both interventions.
population_specificity: Informal caregivers of patients with Alzheimer's disease in the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions on psychological well-being, burnout, and PTSD symptoms among working registered nurses.
results_summary: Meta-analysis showed mindfulness-based interventions were more effective than passive comparators in reducing psychological distress, stress, depression, and burnout-personal accomplishment. Compared to active comparators, they were more effective in reducing psychological distress and equally effective in reducing stress, anxiety, depression, and burnout. Evidence on PTSD effects was scarce.
population_specificity: Working registered nurses (1,077 participants across 14 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) and mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) on quality of life, pain, fatigue, anxiety, and depression in cancer patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that MBSR/MBCT interventions had a significant positive effect on quality of life (SMD 0.80) in cancer patients, though specific effects on pain, fatigue, anxiety, and depression were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how baseline participant characteristics influence the outcomes of meditation interventions.
results_summary: Higher baseline psychopathology or depression was linked to worsened mental health after meditation, while higher interpersonal variables, motivation, medical conditions, and mindfulness predicted better outcomes. Well-being and stress were associated with both positive and negative meditation outcomes.
population_specificity: 7,782 participants across 51 studies, with varied baseline characteristics (e.g., psychopathology, well-being, interpersonal traits).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the contributions of focused attention (FA) and open monitoring (OM) meditation practices to emotional and training outcomes in mindfulness-based interventions like MBCT.
results_summary: FA and MBCT trainings produced significant leftward shifts in frontal alpha asymmetry, associated with positive affect, and improved self-reported emotional responses to negative images. OM training showed limited benefits, restricted to subjective outcomes.
population_specificity: Community adults with varying levels of depressive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of a Mindfulness-Based Intervention (MBI) on Theory of Mind (ToM) ability in individuals with psychotic disorders.
results_summary: The study found that participants receiving Integrated Rehabilitation Treatment (IRT) plus MBI scored higher on the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (RMET) post-treatment compared to those receiving IRT alone, suggesting MBI may improve ToM ability in psychosis.
population_specificity: 36 participants diagnosed with psychotic disorder recruited from a community center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of non-pharmacological interventions, including mindfulness, in reducing pain intensity in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness significantly reduced pain intensity in MS patients (SMD -0.55, 95% CI -0.96 to -0.14, P = 0.009), indicating a meaningful therapeutic effect.
population_specificity: Adults with multiple sclerosis experiencing pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the safety and preliminary efficacy of a psychoeducation program combined with mindfulness exercises (PSYCH-Mind) for improving executive functions and quality of life in PD-MCI patients.
results_summary: Both interventions (PSYCH-Mind and Adapted-GMT) improved executive functions, but only PSYCH-Mind significantly increased quality of life at the four-week follow-up. The interventions were feasible and safe, with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's Disease Mild Cognitive Impairment (PD-MCI) and mild executive dysfunctions.
effective_dosage: Five sessions, each lasting 60-90 minutes, over five weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate factors influencing mindfulness among clinical nurses in China, focusing on its relationship with anxiety, stress perception, resilience, and emotion regulation.
results_summary: The study found that anxiety, stress perception, emotional exhaustion, and expressive suppression negatively affected mindfulness, while mental resilience and cognitive reappraisal positively influenced it. Nurses had higher-than-normal mindfulness levels, with a mean score near the high-medium category cutoff.
population_specificity: 358 clinical nurses from Beijing Aerospace Center Hospital.

study_goal: To examine the effects of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on psychological distress and mindfulness in incarcerated populations.
results_summary: MBIs showed moderate effects on depressive symptoms and overall psychological distress, large effects on stress, and small effects on anxiety and mindfulness. The overall risk of bias across studies was unclear.
population_specificity: Incarcerated individuals (prison or jail populations)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize meta-analyses on sport psychology techniques, including mindfulness, to assess their overall impact on athletic performance.
results_summary: Mindfulness was among the sport psychology interventions shown to have a moderate beneficial effect on athletic performance (d = 0.51). The study did not isolate mindfulness-specific results but included it as part of broader psychological techniques.
population_specificity: Athletes (specific sport or level not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of brief adolescent mindfulness (BAM) versus motivational interviewing (MI) in reducing problem drinking among adolescents and to examine neural responses to therapist language.
results_summary: Both BAM and MI groups showed significant reductions in problem drinking at 3 and 6 months, but MI outperformed BAM at 12 months. Neural responses to therapist language differed between groups, with some brain changes associated with reduced problem drinking at 12 months.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 15-19 with problem drinking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acceptability, feasibility, and effectiveness of the ACORN intervention, which included mindfulness exercises, in reducing prenatal anxiety among pregnant individuals.
results_summary: The ACORN intervention showed positive engagement rates (77% attended at least one session) and resulted in a larger reduction in anxiety levels compared to usual care (Cohen's d = 0.42). Feedback from participants was favorable, suggesting the intervention was acceptable and beneficial.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals with elevated anxiety symptoms (GAD-7 score ≥7) attending prenatal clinics in London and Exeter, UK, and their partners.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to be short-term (likely weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mobile-based mindfulness intervention (MLWI) compared to mobile-based cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT-I) in treating insomnia.
results_summary: The study will assess sleep quality, insomnia severity, and sleep activity as primary outcomes, along with stress, anxiety, depression, and mindfulness as secondary outcomes. Results will be measured at baseline, post-intervention, and 3-month follow-up, but specific findings are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: 250 participants with insomnia.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions (2 sessions per week, 30 minutes each) over 6 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of remotely delivered interventions, including mindfulness, in reducing anxiety symptoms among pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found that remotely delivered interventions, including mindfulness, showed a beneficial effect in reducing anxiety scores, particularly when combined with therapist contact or peer support. However, the findings should be interpreted cautiously due to limited data and study quality.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with symptoms of anxiety, depression, fear of childbirth, insomnia, or preterm labor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the psychological effects of online-based mindfulness programs during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The review found that online-based mindfulness interventions may have favorable effects for reducing psychological problems such as anxiety, depression, and stress, based on six RCTs with varying risk of bias.
population_specificity: Clinical populations, healthy individuals, and healthcare workers with psychological problems due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between emotional dysregulation and emotional eating, with mindfulness as a potential mediator in female patients with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).
results_summary: The study found that emotional eating was negatively correlated with mindfulness (r = -0.383; p = 0.026), suggesting that higher mindfulness is associated with lower emotional eating. Additionally, self-compassion mediated the relationship between emotional dysregulation and emotional eating.
population_specificity: 51 female individuals diagnosed with GAD, 34 of whom completed all questionnaires.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to integrate the features of therapeutic meditation in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to assess its benefits for populations with diseases.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based, yoga-based, and transcendental meditation showed positive outcomes, particularly for sleep (73.9%) and fatigue (68.4%), among 10,139 participants with 45 kinds of disorders. The most frequently assessed symptoms included depressive mood, anxiety, quality of life, stress, sleep, pain, and fatigue.
population_specificity: Participants with various diseases/disorders, most commonly cancer, musculoskeletal and connective tissue diseases, and affective mood disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a midwifery intervention could increase maternal self-efficacy and reduce stress levels during the first six months after birth.
results_summary: The study found that the PSS score (stress level) was statistically higher in the control group than in the intervention group at T1, suggesting the intervention may have reduced stress. Further exploration is needed to address maternal individual needs for successful motherhood transition.
population_specificity: Women aged >18 years who delivered at or beyond term with normal APGAR scores for their infants, recruited from two hospitals in Rome, Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of mindfulness exercise guided by a smartphone app on reducing negative emotions and stress in a non-clinical population with emotional symptoms.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that mindfulness exercise guided by a smartphone app reduced negative emotions and stress, though the results should be interpreted cautiously due to methodological weaknesses and a lack of RCTs.
population_specificity: Non-clinical population with emotional symptoms

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of coach-guided videoconferencing acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) with psychoeducation on psychological distress and quality of life in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in depression, anxiety, stress, grief, engagement in meaningful activities, and self-compassion, with medium to large effect sizes. However, there were no significant changes in quality of life, resilience, or ACT processes.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) experiencing psychological distress.
effective_dosage: 8 individual videoconferencing sessions (specific duration per session not mentioned).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated (implied by 8 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility, acceptability, and potential synergy of combining mindful meditation (MM) with RAVANS for chronic low back pain (CLBP), as well as possible moderators of its effects.
results_summary: MM+RAVANS was well tolerated and feasible, with both MM+stimulation sessions improving pain severity and thresholds. Greater negative affect enhanced pain relief from MM+RAVANS, while higher mindfulness improved outcomes with MM+sham.
population_specificity: Nineteen adults with chronic low back pain and prior mindful meditation training.
study_duration: Two sessions (one with RAVANS, one with sham stimulation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness training as a psychological intervention for managing various female sexual dysfunctions (FSDs).
results_summary: Mindfulness training was found to be effective for the management of several different FSDs, alongside other psychological interventions like cognitive-behavior therapy and sensate focus. The abstract does not provide specific details on the magnitude of mindfulness's effects compared to other interventions.
population_specificity: Women with female sexual dysfunctions (FSDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of diving combined with mindfulness exercises (Bathysmed® protocol) versus multisport activity in reducing PTSD symptoms and improving mindfulness functioning.
results_summary: The Bathysmed® protocol improved PTSD symptoms more than multisport, though not significantly, and significantly reduced intrusion symptoms after one month. Trait mindfulness scores improved up to one month but not significantly, with no differences between groups at three months.
population_specificity: Subjects suffering from PTSD.
study_duration: One month (with follow-up at three months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a mindfulness app, with and without supporting classes, for reducing employees' perceived stress and improving mental health, productivity, and workplace behaviors.
results_summary: The app combined with classes reduced psychological distress and increased mindfulness, but self-guided app use alone showed no significant benefits. Observer measures indicated that app+classes participants were more mindful and altruistic at work by the 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Tasmanian State Service employees
effective_dosage: Recommended 10-20 minutes, 5 days a week (actual usage was lower: app+classes ~120/343 minutes, app-only ~45/343 minutes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether delivering Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) as part of a teacher-training program could reduce perceived stress among lower secondary school teachers.
results_summary: The intervention group showed statistically significant reductions in perceived stress scores (measured by Cohen's Perceived Stress Scale) compared to the wait-list control group at both 3 and 6 months, with greater reductions observed at the 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Lower secondary school teachers in Denmark.
study_duration: The intervention was delivered during 2019 (exact duration not specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a nurse-led mindfulness-based Tai Chi Chuan (MTCC) program in increasing posttraumatic growth (PTG) and reducing perceived stress and anxiety in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The MTCC group showed significantly higher PTG levels and lower perceived stress and anxiety compared to the control group after the 8-week intervention and at the one-year follow-up. The program was deemed simple, effective, and suitable for clinical nurses to recommend to cancer survivors.
population_specificity: Women with stage I-III breast cancer (n=59).
effective_dosage: 8-week program, twice a week, one-hour sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a brief psychological support intervention, including mindfulness-based exercises, improved adherence to noninvasive ventilation (NIV) and quality of life in patients with COPD.
results_summary: The psychological intervention, which included mindfulness, significantly improved adherence to NIV and quality of life compared to the control group, with notable improvements observed after eight meetings. The intervention also showed a significant positive change in quality of life over time.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who had an indication for noninvasive ventilation (NIV).
effective_dosage: Four to eight meetings (structured for hospital, home, and/or telemedicine settings).
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated, but outcomes were measured after eight meetings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) alone and combined with an organizational health intervention on mindfulness and other mental health outcomes in teachers.
results_summary: MBSR had positive short-term effects on mindfulness (total score, 'observing', and 'non-reactivity') and work engagement ('dedication'), with long-term benefits for mindfulness, sleep quality, negative emotions, and work-home interaction. However, no significant effects were found for work performance, personal competencies, or work-related perceptions.
population_specificity: Teachers in Dutch secondary vocational schools
study_duration: Data collected before (T0), immediately after (T1), and at 3 (T2) and 9 months (T3) post-intervention

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two low-intensity outreach programs (care management and brief dialectical behavior therapy skills training, including mindfulness) versus usual care in preventing suicidal behavior among outpatients with frequent suicidal thoughts.
results_summary: The study found that brief dialectical behavior therapy skills training (including mindfulness) significantly increased the risk of self-harm compared to usual care, while care management showed no significant reduction in self-harm risk. Neither intervention outperformed usual care in preventing severe or broader self-harm.
population_specificity: Adult outpatients (18,644 participants, 67% female, 50% from mental health specialty clinics) reporting frequent suicidal thoughts identified via routine depression screening at four US integrated health systems.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions included mindfulness, mindfulness of current emotion, opposite action, and paced breathing, delivered primarily through electronic health record online messaging).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility and acceptability of delivering a combined online Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) and exercise pain management programme for adults with chronic pain, and to assess the viability of a future randomised controlled trial.
results_summary: The study will evaluate feasibility and acceptability metrics such as recruitment, adherence, and engagement, alongside descriptive comparisons of clinical treatment effects using patient-reported outcomes, but final results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic pain in Ireland.
effective_dosage: 2 hours of MBSR and 1 hour of supervised exercise per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of motor imagery-based brain-computer interface (MI-BCI) for upper limb rehabilitation in chronic stroke survivors and study early event-related desynchronization post-intervention.
results_summary: The study found that participants could successfully control a virtual marble game using their sensorimotor rhythm, with observed ipsilesional and contralesional brain activity, supporting MI-BCI's feasibility for stroke rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors with upper limb disability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a Motor Imagery-based EEG visual neurofeedback system for improving motor learning and clinical outcomes in individuals with complete spinal cord injury during passive walking.
results_summary: The study found increased sensitivity to light touch and painful discrimination, improved neurogenic bladder and bowel functions, and enhanced brain connectivity, particularly in the motor cortex. Both participants also showed improved μ rhythm modulation, suggesting motor learning.
population_specificity: Two individuals with complete spinal cord injury (SCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of motor imagery-based brain-computer interface rehabilitation programs on upper extremity hand function in chronic hemiplegia stroke patients.
results_summary: The BCI group showed significant activation in multiple brain regions during motor and imagery tasks, along with improved motor function scores (FMA-UE) correlated with specific neural changes. The study concluded that BCI therapy is effective and safe for arm rehabilitation post-stroke.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients with upper limb motor dysfunction (40 completed the study).

study_goal: To assess the feasibility of a home-based Graded Motor Imagery (GraMI) protocol for amputees with phantom limb pain.
results_summary: The study found high adherence (89.32%) and no participant dropouts, with significant (p = .005) and clinically relevant pain reduction (>2 points) in the experimental group. No significant differences were observed between groups (p = .054).
population_specificity: Twenty individuals over 18 years with upper or lower limb amputation experiencing phantom limb pain, pharmacologically stable, and discharged from the hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a questionnaire (AOMI-AQ) to assess the ability of participants to perform combined action observation and motor imagery (AOMI).
results_summary: The AOMI-AQ demonstrated positive correlations with existing motor-imagery measures and showed good test-retest reliability, indicating it is a valid and reliable tool for assessing AOMI ability.
population_specificity: General adult participants (211 in Study 1 and 174 in Study 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of motor imagery on balance and mobility in stroke patients compared to conventional treatments.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in Time Up and Go Test (TUGT), Berg Balance Scale (BBS), and Movement Imagery Questionnaire (MIQ-3) after eight weeks of motor imagery training, indicating better balance and mobility. No statistically significant difference was observed in the Functional Reach Test (FRT) between groups, but within-group analysis showed improvements across all measures.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (mean age 52.63 ±8.78 years, n=30).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether action observation combined with motor imagery (AO + MI) could improve recovery of upper extremity function in post-stroke patients compared to standard physical therapy.
results_summary: The experimental group (AO + MI) showed improvements in function and strength, with increased alpha desynchronization in the premotor cortex of the injured hemisphere, suggesting enhanced neural activity related to movement preparation and learning. A negative correlation was found between supplementary motor area desynchronization and functional improvement.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients with upper extremity paresis (n=11).
effective_dosage: 10-12 sessions of physical therapy (AO + MI for the experimental group).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to span the 10-12 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a home-based, self-delivered prehabilitation intervention combining motor imagery and tDCS for improving mobility in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that home-based tDCS is safe and feasible for older adults, and motor imagery practice may augment motor learning and performance, though preliminary efficacy data for mobility improvement is still being collected.
population_specificity: Adults aged 70-95 who self-reported a fall in the prior 12 months or had a fear of falling.
effective_dosage: 20 min of 2.0-mA tDCS to frontal lobes (active group) or 30 s (sham group), combined with motor imagery practice via six instructional videos.
study_duration: Six 40-minute sessions delivered every other day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the effectiveness of Motor Imagery (MI) in improving rehabilitation outcomes for individuals with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Individual studies reported significant improvements in cognitive function (3 articles), motor function (7 articles), quality of life (1 article), and confidence in daily tasks (1 article), but meta-analyses found no statistically significant effects due to study heterogeneity and small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease (320 participants across 12 studies).
